awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Ascertaining Intergovernmental Coordination Mechanisms 

Abstract: 
Jurisdictional boundaries of governmental agencies often do not align with the geographic or social boundaries of the policy issues they are tasked with addressing. This spatial mismatch is especially common in relation to natural resources and the environment. Where it occurs, achievement of policy goals may require coordination across jurisdictions, which can lead to mutual benefits. Yet, governmental agencies may view coordination as costly or as leading to a loss of autonomy. This project will examine the choices of local governmental agencies as they respond to a State legislative mandate to coordinate in order to achieve groundwater sustainability.
  
The project will investigate coordination decisions made by Groundwater Sustainability Agencies (GSAs) as they coordinate plans under California's Sustainable Groundwater Management Act (SGMA). The project will employ a mixed-methods approach, including interviews, surveys, content analysis, and statistical modeling, to analyze differences in coordination mechanisms among various GSAs. To do so, the research will examine compatibility between groundwater sustainability plans submitted by GSAs which share a groundwater basin, as well as the fit of those plans with SGMA statutory definitions of groundwater sustainability at the basin-level. Though the research examines coordination over shared groundwater, findings will be applicable more broadly to the management of other shared natural resources and cross-border environmental issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research contributes new understandings of mandated coordination and furthers theorizing as to how interagency coordination occurs in multi-level governance. 

Data was collected on agency interactions and planning during the phase of initial groundwater sustainability plan development by the critically overdrafted basins under SGMA (2017-2020). Data collection included interviews, participant observation and attendance in public meetings, and secondary data including interagency agreements, meeting minutes, news articles, and groundwater sustainability plans, among others. Analysis included qualitative coding, QCA, GIS and regression.

Research results indicate that when mandated to coordinate, agencies have concerns about loss of autonomy, the distribution of costs and benefits, the potential for defection, and the implications of noncompliance with the mandate. These concerns influence the mechanisms agencies adopt for working together. When the mandate allows agencies to choose how how they will coordinate with one another, if agencies do not have autonomy concerns, they will generally engage in fully joint decision-making. If one or more agencies have intransigent autonomy concerns, the agencies will engage in deliberative-only decision-making. Otherwise, agencies will employ a coordination mechanism that employs some form of joint decision-making, the scope of which will depend how agencies balance their autonomy concerns with their concerns about compliance with the mandate, distribution of responsibilities, and any potential mutual gains from working together. 

Research results also show that the institutional arrangements agencies use to coordinate with one another influence whether coordination is achieved.  Greater collaboration does not necessarily equal greater coordination; rather, both agencies that developed new formal structures that merged across jurisdictional boundaries and agencies that maintained existing boundaries achieved both coordinated and uncoordinated outcomes. Rather than formal structure, how interactions occur within the formal structure was key to coordination outcomes. The interagency interactions needed to achieve coordination varies with the type of outcome being coordinated. Groundwater sustainability plans that were well-coordinated in developing knowledge of the groundwater basin; across policy goals; and across policy actions adopted collaborative forums for deliberation and collaborative processes for evaluation and for plan approval. However, collaborative forums for deliberation are not needed for coordinating oversight of plan implementation.

Project outputs include: 4 published articles, 1 book chapter, 1 PhD thesis, additionaly journal manuscripts under review or in preparation, and a handbook on interagency coordination. Results were presented during meetings held directly with state agencies, at international working groups on transboundary waters, and at academic conferences.

Undergraduate and graduate students received interdisciplinary training in relation to groundwater, hydrogeology, institutional theory, and collaborative policy. Students also developed and improved their writing and oral presentation skills.
